The 18th century meteorologist George Hadley was the first to suggest the existence of
a circulation pattern, now known as the Hadley Sal.
He thought warm air rising at the equator would move toward the north and south poles,
and he figured that when the air reached the cold temperatures around the poles it would
sink and head back along the ground toward the equator.
That pattern was a highly simplified version of what average circulation really looks like.
One important difference between Hadley's concept and reality is the effect of the Earth's
rotation.
Instead of a single large pattern developing, the planet's rotation causes three small
circulation patterns or cells to develop in each hemisphere.
In the northern hemisphere, the first cell has warm air rising at the equator, then moving
northward.
But instead of making it all the way to the north pole, the air sinks to the surface
at about 30 degrees north.
It then moves back along the surface towards the equator.
Because of the rotation of the Earth, the air movement is deflected to the right in
the northern hemisphere, causing winds to blow from the north and east.
The second of the three circulation cells is called the feral cell after its discoverer.
In the northern hemisphere, it also has air sinking at about 30 degrees north latitude,
but instead of heading back towards the equator like the Hadley cell, this one continues
to move northward along the ground.
It rises again at about 60 degrees north and then heads south at high altitude to complete
its circuit.
Winds in that pattern are also deflected to the right so they flow along the ground from
the west or southwest.
The final pattern is called the polar cell.
It has cold air moving southward along the surface from the Arctic.
At about 60 degrees north latitude it rises, then heads back towards the Arctic.
The surface winds in that system blow out of the east.
